title: could kill you
intro: In a competition for control between laughter and breathing and speaking, laughter always wins, says a neuroscientist. Neil and Tim discuss the dangers of laughter and teach you some related words.
this_week_question: How many times a day does the average adult laugh? Is it…
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a loud laugh that you can't control
laugh very loudly for a long time
to stop breathing because something is blocking your throat
the sheet of muscle separating your lungs from your stomach

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you an entertaining topic and six related items of vocabulary. I'm Neil… and those guffaws you can hear are coming from Tim. So what's so funny, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Can you pass me a glass of water?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, OK, here you go.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: It was just something our producer said before I came into the studio. A guffaw by the way is a loud laugh that you can't control...

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So while Tim laughs his head off – and that means to laugh very loudly for a long time – I'll introduce the show. Today, Tim, we're talking about laughter and how it could kill you…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Oh come on, Neil! That's not funny! Laughing is good for you – everyone knows that!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, not when you laugh like that, Tim! You're bright red in the face, you've got tears streaming down your face. And you nearly choked on a glass of water! Choke means to stop breathing because something is blocking your throat by the way. Now, without laughing or choking, can you please tell me how many times a day the average adult laughs? Is it… a) 17, b) 70 or c) 700?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Hmm. Surely it depends on what type of person you are?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Maybe it does. That's why I'm asking about the average number of times Tim, so just make an intelligent guess. Tim OK, well I laugh a lot so I'm going to say 70 times a day. 700 times seems like you'd be laughing all the time… But you've worried, me Neil – I know we sometimes say, I nearly died laughing – but nobody does actually die laughing, do they?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I think the risk of dying of laughter is probably low – but in theory, what happens when we laugh is potentially dangerous! Let's listen to cognitive neuroscientist Sophie Scott talking about what happens when we laugh.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Sophie Scott, cognitive neuroscientist Laughter – in a competition for control over your ribcage in your brain between laughter and breathing and speaking – laughter will always win. And laughter just takes those same muscles and it squeezes them – eh eh eh eh – and the air goes – out out out out – and notably it does not want to let you breathe in. It's trying to kill you. It's quite dangerous.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: So when you laugh a lot your diaphragm – that's the sheet of muscle below your lungs – contracts and squeezes the air out of your lungs.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: This makes it hard to breathe – which is why you were gasping for breath earlier, Tim! And that's why laughter can kill you!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Gasping means having difficulty breathing. Well, I've caught my breath now – I didn't die – and I think it's fair to say, Neil, that laughter is good for you. When you laugh, your body releases happy hormones… And according to some research, people feel less pain as a result of having a good laugh.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So scientists are saying laughter is a sort of natural painkiller?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Apparently, yes. They've done research where they make people laugh, and then test their pain levels afterwards. And they found that if people only chuckle a bit it doesn't act as a painkiller, but if you laugh a lot, it does.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So a chuckle sounds like this [chuckles]. Chuckling means to laugh quietly. So you need belly laughter then – great big guffaws? Tim That's right. A guffaw is pretty much the opposite of a chuckle. I was guffawing earlier in the show. Would you like to demonstrate your own guffaw, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: [hearty guffaw]

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Fantastic – can I try pinching you now, and test whether you feel any pain?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, you can't, Tim. It's time for the answer to today's quiz question. I asked you:

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I said 70…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sorry. The right answer is actually 17 – less than you thought I'm afraid, Tim. But children laugh on average 300 times a day.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: That's a big difference! You see, Neil, we all need to laugh more. You shouldn't be trying to tell us that laughing is dangerous.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Maybe you're right. So let's move on and go over the words we learned today. The first one is 'guffaw' – which is a loud laugh that you can't control...

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “Neil surprised us with his deep guffaw.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Next up – number two – to 'laugh your head off' – means to laugh very loudly for a long time.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “It's a really funny movie – you'll laugh your head off!”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK – number three – 'choke' means to stop breathing because something is blocking your throat.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “I nearly choked to death on a cheese sandwich.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Poor Tim – you should eat more slowly! 'Diaphragm' is our next word, and that's the sheet of muscle separating your lungs from your stomach. We use our diaphragms for breathing, talking, and laughing!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “Do opera singers have more powerful diaphragms than other people?”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I don't know the answer to that, Tim. So number five, which is 'gasping', which means having difficulty breathing. “He was gasping for breath as he swam to the surface of the swimming pool.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: But 'gasp' also means to be shocked or surprised by something. For example, “I gasped in astonishment when I heard Neil laugh.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Our final word is 'chuckle' which means to laugh quietly.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “The audience chuckled through the show but they didn't seem very amused.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh dear. Well I hope our audience has been amused today. If you're looking for more laughs, then please check out our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages. You may find something to make you chuckle or guffaw there.

transcript.author: Tim and Neil
transcript.text: Bye!
